Many of them were very famous, and five were in Kent: Chilham Castle, Ingress Abbey, Leeds Abbey, North Cray Place, and Valence near Westerham.

Horace Walpole (1717-97)

Horatio Walpole, the 4th Earl of Orford, was the only son of Britain’s first Prime Minister, Sir Robert Walpole. Not surprisingly, after following his father to Cambridge, he became a Whig MP for nearly three decades, representing three different constituencies. Yet it was as an author that he made his name. He was a prolific writer of letters, which have been published in 40 volumes, containing much of political and social interest. In his forties, he wrote ‘The Castle of Otranto’, a medieval thriller. It was in fact the first Gothic novel, and would inspire the likes of EA Poe and Bram Stoker. Walpole was fascinated by medievalism, to the extent that he’d had an extraordinary mock-Gothic castle, Strawberry Hill House, built near Twickenham. Among his friends, the lifelong bachelor Walpole counted Edward Mann, owner of the altogether more traditional Linton Park, south of Maidstone; Walpole was a keen visitor.

Samuel Foote (1720-77)

With a first cousin who was insane, and one uncle who murdered another over a will, Foote unsurprisingly behaved like he had a screw loose. The son of a Cornish MP, he was sent down from Oxford, and joined the theatre in London. He had a talent for making people laugh, being a superlative mimic, and was responsible for numerous satirical productions, some of them highly successful. The trouble was that, apart from playing fast and loose with both money and the law, he got his laughs by expertly ridiculing real people. One hilarious example was ‘The Author’ (1757), which ridiculed the literary patron John Apreece so excruciatingly that he got it banned. In fact, Foote made enemies galore who devoted themselves to avenging themselves, and after losing a leg in a riding accident was lampooned as the ‘Devil on Two Sticks’. His only lasting legacy was the expression ‘Grand Panjandrum’. He died at Dover en route to France.

John Smeaton (1724-92)

A lawyer’s son from Yorkshire, John Smeaton became an instrument-maker. He showed such precocious talent in his twenties – designing for example a pyrometer to measure expansion – that he was elected a fellow of the Royal Society in 1753, and then won the Copley Medal. His fertile mind’s fruits included cement hardened by water, a water-engine and watermill, and Seaton’s coefficient for calculating lift, later refined by the Wright brothers. He made his fortune from engineering projects, however, and founded the Society of Civil Engineers, so named to differentiate their discipline from the military skills taught at Woolwich. Though his most famous achievement was Eddystone Lighthouse in Cornwall, later rebuilt on Plymouth Hoe as ‘Smeaton’s Tower’, he undertook many years of ingenious and painstaking work at Ramsgate to establish a viable harbour and jetty, even pioneering the use of a new form of diving bell. He was mentioned in a 2004 Kaiser Chiefs song as an emblem of better times.

Joseph Priestley (1733-1804)

Although best remembered for scientific discoveries, Yorkshireman Joseph Priestley was primarily a man of the cloth. A Calvinist dissenter, he became interested in physical laws in the belief that better knowledge of God’s work would improve the human lot. In addition to inventing carbonated water in 1767, he discovered the existence of gases, among them oxygen – which he called ‘de-phlogisticated air’ – in 1774. That same year he attended a Unitarian meeting in Tenterden with Benjamin Franklin, whom he had consulted whilst writing ‘The History and Present State of Electricity’ (1767). His scientific credibility was ultimately undermined by his dogged adherence to phlogiston theory; but it was his political beliefs that brought him public opprobrium. A supporter of the American and French Revolutions, he wrote a critique of Burke’s anti-revolutionary tract ‘Reflections on the French Revolution’ that had a mob up in arms, and his house and church in Birmingham were burned. He fled to America, and died in Pennsylvania.

George III, King of England (1738-1820)

Since he had what it takes to rule Great Britain for nearly 60 years – then a record – it’s a pity that George III is only remembered now for two things: losing his American colonies, and losing his marbles. There’s no denying that Mad King George had a serious problem: he suffered from an illness, possibly porphyry, that increasingly debilitated him. Yet, in his time, the nation underwent the Industrial Revolution, defeated France in the Seven Years’ War, and overcame the mortal threat of Napoleon. In 1778, he stayed at Leeds Castle with Queen Charlotte when visiting an Army camp, but his most conspicuous visit to Kent entailed an occasion in 1799 when Lord Romney invited the royal family to his estate at Mote Park in Maidstone. By 1810, however, George’s mind was so far gone that his son had to rule as Prince Regent throughout his last decade.

Field Marshall von Blücher (1742-1819)

Ask any German who won the Battle of Waterloo and you’ll get one answer: Blücher. By their account, Wellington was hanging on by his fingernails when the Prussians arrived like the US cavalry to win the day. However one regards it, his arrival was most welcome, if a little tardy. Gebhard von Blücher was born in Rostock, and ironically was taken prisoner by the Prussian Army in 1760 while fighting for Sweden. He became the outstanding Prussian general, taking on Napoleon more times than any other and matching him for belligerence. In 1814, after decisively defeating the French army at Leipzig, Blücher was invited to Britain to celebrate Napoleon’s abdication, along with several other allied war-leaders. After landing at Dover, they were given a sumptuous reception, which included visiting the Woolwich Arsenal. Unfortunately, the festivities were premature. Within months, Napoleon would escape and form a new army that was to test Blücher’s determination one last time.

James Wyatt (1746-1813)

At 15, Staffordshire-born Wyatt went for six years to Italy where, as part of his architectural education, he had the misfortune to be slung on a ladder 300 feet up in St Peter’s Basilica without protection. Having survived, he was handed a golden break by his brother, by whose efforts he was commissioned to design the Pantheon in Oxford Street, described by Horace Walpole as England’s loveliest building. He went on to win scores of further commissions, including several Oxford colleges, and in Kent alone designed Hothfield Place, Lee Priory, and Sundridge Park, as well as the Royal Arsenal, Royal Artillery Barracks, and Royal Military Academy at Woolwich. He also undertook numerous radical alterations to historic buildings, earning him the sobriquet ‘Wyatt the Destroyer’ – which perhaps explains his surprising anonymity compared with his contemporaries Nash and the Adams brothers. Briefly president of the Royal Academy of Arts, he died after a road accident, and was buried at Westminster Abbey.

Fanny Burney (1752-1840)

Born into a well-to-do musician’s family in Norfolk, Frances Burney took up writing fiction in her twenties. Her first novel, a three-volume effort called ‘Evelina’ (1778), was published under a pseudonym, though her identity came out. It concerned the experiences of a well-born young woman making her way in Georgian society, observed with a sardonic eye that evidently impressed Jane Austen a generation later. Other novels followed, plus dramas that were mostly ignored in Burney’s lifetime. Her most valuable output was the journals she commenced at 15 and maintained for 72 years. They covered everything from a visit to Knole Park, Sevenoaks in 1783 to an excruciating mastectomy she underwent at 59. Burney served as Queen Charlotte‘s Keeper of the Robes before becoming Madame d’Arblay, the wife of a French general, and being exiled in France for a decade because of Napoleon’s war with Britain. She later settled in Bath, and died at a ripe old age.

General Count Matvei Ivanovich Platov (1753-1818)

Among the dignitaries who arrived at Dover in 1814 to celebrate the provisional defeat of Napoleon was Count Platov, general of the Don Cossacks throughout the Napoleonic Wars, who was escorting the much younger tsar Alexander I. Hailing from southern Russia, he had joined the Cossacks at 12, fought in several campaigns, and become their ataman (commander) in 1801. At the pivotal battle of Borodino in 1812, his attack on the French left so discomfited Napoleon that he fatefully withheld his elite Imperial Guard. The crucial import of this was only appreciated later, however, and Platov temporarily lost face following Russia’s apparent defeat. Then, however, he harassed the Grande Armée all the way back to France, with devastating effect. By the time he visited Kent, he was a household name, albeit misspelt Platoff, and was commemorated in paint at General Beresford’s expense. Had he been at Waterloo the following year, Napoleon’s fate might have been settled rather faster.

Talleyrand (1754-1838)

Charles-Maurice de Talleyrand-Périgord was Tony Blair without the principles. He started as a churchman and, as a bishop, joined the États Généraux, where he cynically pontificated against the Church. He fled for England when Robespierre took over, but was obliged to return in 1794 when fellow refugees turned against him. He ingratiated himself with Napoleon, who saw him as a weapon in international negotiations, even though he secretly worked against Napoleon’s interests. The interests that concerned him most were his own, especially living in splendour at Valençay and siring dozens of illegitimate children. His greatest achievement was brilliantly saving France from dismemberment at the Congress of Vienna in 1814-5, which made his reputation as the world’s craftiest diplomat. Afterwards, he was sidelined during the reign of Charles X, but returned in 1830 as Ambassador to Great Britain. He relished being greeted at Dover by tricolour-waving crowds and a cannonade, 36 years after returning to revolutionary France under a cloud.

General von Bülow (1755-1816)

Although Blücher is synonymous with the Prussian Army at Waterloo, the contribution of Friedrich Wilhelm, Freiherr von Bülow, cannot be underrated. He was a career soldier who worked his way up through the ranks with aplomb. Strangely, he first came to the attention of Frederick the Great through his musical ability, which won’t have hindered his assiduous pursuit of a military career. Von Bülow distinguished himself as a general late in the Napoleonic Wars, when he excelled in the defence of Berlin, and then in the crucial defeat of the French at Leipzig. He did not always get on with Blücher, there inevitably being rivalry between these two great contemporaneous Prussian generals; but he served the Field Marshall well in the defeat of Napoleon in 1814. He came to Kent for the victory celebrations that June, before adding further to his personal glory at Waterloo, where his brigade played a crucial role in finishing off the Grande Armée.

Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart (1756-91)

Having been born into a wealthy family at Salzburg, Austria, Mozart developed a precocious musical ability that became unmistakable when he wrote his first symphony at 8. As his older sister Nannerl was also a talented pianist, their composer father Leopold took them on a European tour so that the children could perform for high society. From April 1764 they spent more than 15 months in England, including a few days in Kent when Mozart performed at Canterbury. They stayed at Bourne House as guests of Sir Horatio Mann, and possibly also Egerton House and Higham Park. Young Mozart went on to become arguably the greatest composer in history, responsible for 600 works including 22 operas and dozens of symphonies. Plagued by money troubles, however, he was hit by depression and then illness. He died suddenly at 35, and was buried in an unmarked grave. We can only imagine what musical wonders he might have produced in his maturity.

William Blake (1757-1827)

William Blake was one of the giants of the Romantic era, excelling not only in painting but also poetry. He was quite possibly mad; certainly his contemporaries thought so. He was at first a painter, and his work so highly original that it inevitably suggested a diseased mind, though today we might see in it a forerunner of Surrealism a hundred years before its time. His first great poetic work ‘Songs of Innocence and of Experience’, illustrated by himself, dwells on the corrupting influence of society on human simplicity. The young Blake took a positive view of both the French and American revolutions, something he came to regret in later life. It is ironic that his most famous work ‘Jerusalem’ is now a great patriotic anthem; it was in fact the product of his deep religious faith. Late in life, Blake came to Shoreham near Sevenoaks to visit the Brotherhood of Ancients, a group of young artists who idolised him.

Thomas Telford (1757-1834)

Thomas Telford was a titan of the golden era of Scottish civil engineering. He was born at Eskdale, close to the English border, and lived in poverty after the early death of his father, a shepherd. He became a stonemason, but made his reputation with a broad variety of engineering tasks that he undertook in Shropshire. Eventually he proved himself so versatile that his friend Robert Southey, the future poet laureate, called him the ‘Colossus of Roads’. In 1830 he came to Kent to build the Whitstable Harbour station at the terminus of the new Canterbury and Whitstable railway line, a project that attracted a galaxy of engineering stars including himself, George and Robert Stephenson, and even IK Brunel. Such was Telford’s mastery of civil engineering that he became the first president of its Institution, remaining so for 14 years. When in 1968 a new town was built in Shropshire, it was naturally named after him.

Nelson (1758-1805)

Although Horatio Nelson was born in Norfolk, Kentish people always treated him as one of their own. Chatham was still central to Britain’s naval might, so Nelson was a regular visitor; and his most famous ship, HMS Victory, was built there. Despite his obvious seamanship, Nelson took a beating in a land assault at Tenerife in 1797, but showed his character by corresponding chivalrously with the defending general afterwards. He subsequently proved himself master of the sea, winning one major victory after another. His tactical genius was matched by his ability to get the most out of his men by keeping them fully in the picture, contrary to the custom of the day. His adulterous relationship with Lady Hamilton and ill-treatment of his wife, though shameful, were publicly tolerated because of his sheer popularity. After losing first an eye and then an arm in battle, Admiral Nelson famously lost his life at Trafalgar at the moment of his greatest triumph.

William Wilberforce (1759-1833)

Wilberforce was born in Yorkshire, the son of a wealthy merchant. After enjoying a sybaritic lifestyle, he was elected MP for Hull. In 1785, after a European tour, he underwent a Damascene conversion, becoming an evangelical Christian. A year later, he was approached by a group of abolitionists asking him to take up leadership of their cause. Despite being deeply conservative, he agreed, and maintained the struggle for nearly five decades. He was aided by his close friend Pitt the Younger, to whom he expressed his ambition to end slavery by political means at Holwood House near Bromley in 1787. He incurred the wrath of William Cobbett – the radical who believed that charity begins at home – for championing the rights of foreigners whilst doing nothing for the British working class. Nevertheless, in 1807, the Slave Trade Act was passed. Wilberforce died three days after the Slavery Abolition Act finally killed off slavery in the British Empire.

The Rennies

A farmer’s son from the Scottish Lowlands, John Rennie (1761-1821) displayed an early talent for mechanics, and studied at Edinburgh University. Initially a millwright, he proved himself as an innovator, especially in substituting cast-iron parts in machinery for wooden ones. He got a place working for James Watt in Shropshire, and in 1791 set up his own engineering business in London. He specialised in canals before moving onto bridges – including his chef d’oeuvre, Waterloo Bridge – as well as lighthouses and harbours. His son, also John (1794-1874), was born in Surrey and educated at Dr Burney’s, Greenwich. He proved a chip off the old block, building the 1825 London Bridge his father had designed before his death, then becoming an innovator in his own right. The two are noted for numerous works in Kent, including at Chatham Dockyard, Ramsgate, Sheerness, and Woolwich, albeit that Rennie senior was unable to save the doomed Chetney Hill project.

William IV, King of the United Kingdom & Ireland (1765-1837)

As George III’s third son, William possibly expected never to reign. At 13, he joined the Royal Navy, seeing action in the American Revolution and serving under his friend Nelson in the West Indies. Then, after becoming the Duke of Clarence in 1789, he took the Irish actress and courtesan Dorothea Bland, alias Mrs Jordan, as his mistress; she bore ten illegitimate offspring, all surnamed FitzClarence, during a 20-year relationship. An occasional guest at Sacketts Hill House in Thanet when travelling to Hanover, he commissioned a monument to his old colleague Rear-Admiral William Fox at Ramsgate church in 1811. Seven years after abandoning Bland, he married Adelaide of Saxe-Meiningen, whose four babies all died. On succeeding his elder brother George IV as William IV in 1830, he resisted the Reform Act and contested abolitionism, claiming from experience that even Highlanders were worse off than Caribbean slaves. Lacking a legitimate heir, the ‘Sailor King’ was succeeded by his niece, Victoria.

Marshal General Jean-de-Dieu Soult, 1st Duke of Dalmatia (1769-1851)

For a future military hero and political eminence, Soult came from an unlikely background, his father being a notary in Occitania in the far south of France. After joining the French Army at 16, he was able to progress rapidly during the revolutionary era. Already chief of staff at the pivotal Battle of Fleurus in 1794, he was a general by the time of Napoleon’s 1799 putsch. After excelling at Austerlitz in 1805, he was placed in charge of the Peninsular War, winning initial success before Wellington drove the French out. Despite renouncing republicanism following Napoleon’s abdication, Soult was his chief of staff at Waterloo in 1815. Following exile, he returned to take up politics as a monarchist, and in 1838 deputised for Louis-Philippe at a Grand Review at Woolwich dockyard. Despite serving three times as prime minister of France, the chameleonic Soult again declared himself a republican following the February Revolution in 1848.

Friedrich Wilhelm III, King of Prussia (1770-1840)

Friedrich Wilhelm III, König von Preußen may sound a grand personage, but he was in fact far too diffident ever to be a ruler. This was surprising, given that his grandfather was Frederick the Great, Germany’s finest ever monarch; but, there again, his father had been a pleasure-seeker and just the wrong man to have in charge when the French Revolution started. Luckily, the indecisive King’s wife was Queen Luise, who was not only beautiful but also so smart that Napoleon called her Prussia’s best minister. She died suddenly in 1810, but by then had galvanised a group of able commanders who would ultimately turn the tables on the French. The King came to Kent in 1814 with his best general, Blücher, to celebrate Napoleon’s defeat, thus sharing the glory of the true hero. Friedrich Wilhelm would rule for another quarter century, and his son Wilhelm would become the first Kaiser of the united Germany.

William Wordsworth (1770-1850)
